child.pub-comments: "…Maridan morphology and syntax are identical in every respect to that described above for Marithiel, in the same way that MareAmmu and Marityabin have been shown to be sub-dialects" (Tryon 1974: 102).
child.publications: Tryon, Darrell T. 1974. Daly Family Languages, Australia, vol. C-32. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.pub-comments: "It has roughly 20 speakers today, most of whom live on or close to the Daly River Mission" (Tryon 1974: 94). "…Maridan morphology and syntax are identical in every respect to that described above for Marithiel, in the same way that MareAmmu and Marityabin have been shown to be sub-dialects" (Tryon 1974: 102).
child.publications: Tryon, Darrell T. 1974. Daly Family Languages, Australia, vol. C-32. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.pub-comments: "The Marithiel dialects, then, fall into two groups, on morphological grounds, each with two members, as follows: 1. Marithiel - Maridan, 2. Marityabin - MareAmmu" (Tryon 1974: 103).
child.publications: Tryon, Darrell T. 1974. Daly Family Languages, Australia, vol. C-32. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.pub-comments: "It has roughly 20 speakers today, most of whom live on or close to the Daly River Mission. The traditional home of these people lies somewhere between Hermit Hill and Port Keats" (Tryon 1974: 94). "Within the Daly Family, Marityabin is a member of the Brinken-Wogaity group, and within this is a member of the Brinken subgroup. As stated above, it is a dialect of Marithiel, the other dialects being Maridan and MareAmmu" (Tryon 1974: 94).
child.alt-names: Maridyerbin, Maretyabin, Maretyaben, Murintjabin, Ngangityaben, Tangural, Tanggural
child.publications: Tryon, Darrell T. 1974. Daly Family Languages, Australia, vol. C-32. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.
Tryon, Darrell T. 1974. Daly Family Languages, Australia, vol. C-32. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.pub-comments: "The Marithiel dialects, then, fall into two groups, on morphological grounds, each with two members, as follows: 1. Marithiel - Maridan, 2. Marityabin - MareAmmu" (Tryon 1974: 103).
child.publications: Tryon, Darrell T. 1974. Daly Family Languages, Australia, vol. C-32. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.pub-comments: "Marithiel is spoken today by approximately sixty five speakers, some of whom live at the Daly River, but many of whom live close to European settlements between the Daly River and Darwin" (Tryon 1974: 70). "The term Brinken, however, is not a language name, but rather the name given to a certain group of people speaking Marithiel and its dialects, Marityabin, Maridan and MareAmmu" (Tryon 1974: 70). "The Marithiel dialects, then, fall into two groups, on morphological grounds, each with two members, as follows: 1. Marithiel - Maridan, 2. Marityabin - MareAmmu" (Tryon 1974: 103).
child.alt-names: Maridhiel, Marathiel, Maridiyal, Marithid, Maridiyel, Brinkin, Berinken, Berringin, Bringen
child.publications: Tryon, Darrell T. 1974. Daly Family Languages, Australia, vol. C-32. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.pub-comments: "The traditional territory of Marengar speakers is around the Moyle River near Port Keats… As is the case with other members of the Daly Family, the traditional home has been abandoned as a permanent home for many years, Marengar speakers now living at Port Keats and Daly River and nearby cattle stations. At the present time there would remain only approximately thirty to forty speakers of Marengar as a first language" (Tryon 1974: 120).
child.geography: Moyle River near Port Keats and Daly River
child.publications: Tryon, Darrell T. 1974. Daly Family Languages, Australia, vol. C-32. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.pub-comments: "Maramanandji is spoken today by a maximum of twenty speakers, a few of whom reside at the Daly River and surrounding cattle stations, the remainder living in bush camps closer to Darwin" (Tryon 1974: 104).
child.publications: Tryon, Darrell T. 1974. Daly Family Languages, Australia, vol. C-32. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.
Tryon, Darrell T. 1974. Daly Family Languages, Australia, vol. C-32. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.pub-comments: "It is spoken today by approximately thirty to thirty five aborigines as a first language. Almost all of these people live at Delissaville Settlement, near Darwin, although some Ami speakers are to be found in Darwin itself" (Tryon 1974: 159).
child.publications: Tryon, Darrell T. 1974. Daly Family Languages, Australia, vol. C-32. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.pub-comments: "It is spoken today by approximately twenty five Aborigines, most of whom reside at Delissaville Settlement near Darwin. Some Manda speakers also live in Darwin itself; a few others are to be found at various Daly River settlements. From information given to me by Manda speakers, their traditional territory is on the coast at Anson Bay on the south side of the river" (Tryon 1974: 174).
child.publications: Tryon, Darrell T. 1974. Daly Family Languages, Australia, vol. C-32. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.pub-comments: "It is spoken today by approximately fifteen to twenty aborigines as a first language, althought it is still widely understood throughout the Daly River area… The traditional tribal territory has however been abandoned, the Maranunggu speakers being scattered between the Daly River and Darwin" (Tryon 1974: 138).
child.publications: Tryon, Darrell T. 1974. Daly Family Languages, Australia, vol. C-32. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.
Tryon, Darrell T. 1974. Daly Family Languages, Australia, vol. C-32. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.pub-comments: "It is spoken today by only a handful of old people in and around Darwin" (Tryon 1974: 187). "Wadyiginy poses a problem in classification in that although it shares 79% congnates with Pungupungu, it shows morphological innovations which would certainly impede communication between Pungupungu and Wadyiginy speakers. On lexiostatistical criteria, the two would be dialects, but on morphological cirteria they would almost certainly be considered different languages" (Tryon 1974: 207).
child.publications: Tryon, Darrell T. 1974. Daly Family Languages, Australia, vol. C-32. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.pub-comments: "Batyamal is a sub-dialect of Wadyiginy, just described above. It has approximately twenty surviving speakers, most of whom reside at the Delissaville settlement near Darwin. The name Batyamal has not previously appeared in linguistic literature. It has been termed a 'sub-dialect' rather than a dialect since it shares 90% common cognates with Wadyiginy. Pungupungu, on the other hand, although still a dialect, shares only 79%. As was demonstrated above, Pungupungu totally lacks some of the important morphological features found in Wadyiginy. It is suspected that the two 'sub-dialects', Wadyiginy and Batayamal, may correspond to two lines within the same clan or tribe, a theory put forward also for the 'sub-dialects' which exist within the Brinken Sub-group" (Tryon 1974: 228).
child.publications: Tryon, Darrell T. 1974. Daly Family Languages, Australia, vol. C-32. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.pub-comments: "Wogait is in fact a misnomer for Wadyiginy. Wogait designates a beach dweller anywhere from the mouth of the Daly River to Delissaville, near Darwin. At the present time nearly all Wogait people live at and around Delissaville" (Tryon 1974: 206). "Wadyiginy poses a problem in classification in that although it shares 79% congnates with Pungupungu, it shows morphological innovations which would certainly impede communication between Pungupungu and Wadyiginy speakers. On lexiostatistical criteria, the two would be dialects, but on morphological cirteria they would almost certainly be considered different languages" (Tryon 1974: 207).
child.publications: Tryon, Darrell T. 1974. Daly Family Languages, Australia, vol. C-32. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.pub-comments: This dialect group was added to include both Wadyiginy and Batyamal because of they way the author describes them as sub-dialects. This representation could be wrong, but it seemed to be the best to convey the author's intentions. "It [Batyamal] has been termed a 'sub-dialect' rather than a dialect since it shares 90% common cognates with Wadyiginy. Pungupungu, on the other hand, although still a dialect, shares only 79%. As was demonstrated above, Pungupungu totally lacks some of the important morphological features found in Wadyiginy. It is suspected that the two 'sub-dialects', Wadyiginy and Batayamal, may correspond to two lines within the same clan or tribe, a theory put forward also for the 'sub-dialects' which exist within the Brinken Sub-group" (Tryon 1974: 228).
child.publications: Tryon, Darrell T. 1974. Daly Family Languages, Australia, vol. C-32. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.alt-names: Wogait, Wagatsch, Waggait, Wagaitj, Waggate, Waggites, Waggote, Waogatsch, Wargad, Wogadj, Worgaid, Worgaidj, Wogatj, Wogaity, Wogite, Worgait, Worgite, Wogaidj, Wadjigin, Wadjigi:n, Wagjingi, Wadjingy
child.publications: Tryon, Darrell T. 1974. Daly Family Languages, Australia, vol. C-32. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.
Tryon, Darrell T. 1974. Daly Family Languages, Australia, vol. C-32. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.
Tryon, Darrell T. 1974. Daly Family Languages, Australia, vol. C-32. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.pub-comments: "At present (1973) it [Kamor] is remembered by only three speakers, and then only as a second language. This naturally affects the reliability of the information collected in the field" (Tryon 1974: 62).
child.publications: Tryon, Darrell T. 1974. Daly Family Languages, Australia, vol. C-32. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.pub-comments: "Yunggor, a dialect of Matngala, has the variant spellings Junggor and Yungor. At present it is remembered by only two aborigines as a second language" (Tryon 1974: 56).
child.publications: Tryon, Darrell T. 1974. Daly Family Languages, Australia, vol. C-32. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.
Tryon, Darrell T. 1974. Daly Family Languages, Australia, vol. C-32. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.pub-comments: "Matngala is spoken today by approximately fifteen to twenty Aborigines who are based at Wooliana, on the north bank o fthe Daly River" (Tryon 1974: 42). "Matngala has three dialects, namely Matngala, Kamor and Yunggor" (43).
child.alt-names: Hermit Hill, Amadil, Madngela, Muttangella, Matngelli, Mandella, Madngella, Maangella, Muttangulla, Warat, Ngengiwerat
child.publications: Tryon, Darrell T. 1974. Daly Family Languages, Australia, vol. C-32. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.pub-comments: Author named this node just "Daly." In order to set it apart from the family name which is also "Daly," this subgroup has been called "Daly Proper."
child.publications: Tryon, Darrell T. 1974. Daly Family Languages, Australia, vol. C-32. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.pub-comments: "Tyeraity is spoken to-day by approximately five elderly aborigines who live between Daly River and Darwin" (Tryon 1974: 24). "Apart from a few wordlists, therefore, little information if any has been published on this language. Morphology has been entirely neglected with the exception of notes on noun classifcation (Tryon 1970), so that the position of Tyeraity within the Daly Family has not previously been clarified" (Tryon 1974: 24).
child.alt-names: Djeraity, Djerait, Djeradj, Tjerait, Cherites, Sherait, Tjiras, Daktyeraty, Daktyerat, Djeraidj, Scherits
child.publications: Tryon, Darrell T. 1974. Daly Family Languages, Australia, vol. C-32. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.pub-comments: "Mullukmulluk is spoken to-day by a maximum of forty to fifty Aborigines, most of whom reside at or near Wooliana on the north side of the Daly River" (Tryon 1974: 1).
child.alt-names: Malagmalag, Mullik-Mullik, Mollak-mollak, Malack-malack, Mulluc-Mulluc, Mallackmallack, Ngolok-Wangar, Ngululwanga, Ngulugwanga
child.publications: Tryon, Darrell T. 1974. Daly Family Languages, Australia, vol. C-32. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.pub-comments: Author named this node just "Mulluk." In order to set it apart from the higher subgroup also titled "Mulluk," this subgroup has been called "Mulluk Proper."
child.publications: Tryon, Darrell T. 1974. Daly Family Languages, Australia, vol. C-32. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.
Tryon, Darrell T. 1974. Daly Family Languages, Australia, vol. C-32. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.pub-comments: "The terms beginning with Mare-, Mari- are the names given to Ngenomeri by speakers of Marithiel and other members of the Brinken Sub-group, while the terms beginning with Ngengi- belong to the Tyemeri Group. Both mean language. Ngengomeri is in fact a dialect of Ngangikurrunggurr" (Tryon 1974: 251).
child.geography: Daly River Mission and Tipperary Station
child.alt-names: Angomerry, Nanggumiri, Nangimeri, Ngangomori, Nangumiri, Nangimera, Ngengemeri, Nangiomera, Nangiomeri, Marewumiri, Mariwunini, Ngengewumiri, Mariwumiri
child.publications: Tryon, Darrell T. 1974. Daly Family Languages, Australia, vol. C-32. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.pub-comments: "It is best known as Moil, although this term is in fact geographical; Moil is a Marengar word meaning swamp… The Ngangikurrunggurr language is the largest within the Daly Family, having in excess of one hundred speakers, the majority of who would be children.... At the present time the great majority of speakers live at or near the Daly River Mission, although speakers are to be found in the various settlements and camps between the Daly River and Darwin" (Tryon 1974: 229).
child.alt-names: Tyemeri, Marityemeri, Moil, Ngangikurongor, Ngangikarangurr, Ngangikurrungur
child.publications: Tryon, Darrell T. 1974. Daly Family Languages, Australia, vol. C-32. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.pub-comments: "The Tyemeri Group is rather different from the other Groups within the Family, both lexio-statistically and typologically, although still obviously a member of the Family" (Tryon 1974: 230).
child.publications: Tryon, Darrell T. 1974. Daly Family Languages, Australia, vol. C-32. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

root.publications: Tryon, Darrell T. 1974. Daly Family Languages, Australia, vol. C-32. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.
